bioghist.p: Sigma Pi Phi is generally considered to be the first African-American Greek-lettered organization. Sigma Pi Phi was founded in Philadelphia, in 1904. Sigma Pi Phi, also known as the Boulé ("council of noblemen"), has over 5,000 members and 112 chapters throughout the United States and the West Indies. Unlike many other fraternities, it does not have any college chapters, and its members already have received college and professional degrees at the time of their induction. Shortly after the establishedment of the fraternity, the founders looked to other cities in which to expand the fraternity and thus establish a national organization. The Philadelphia chapter became known as Alpha Boulé, with subsequent chapters named Beta Boulé, Gamma Boulé, and so on. The founders of the fraternity include Henry M. Minton and Algernon B. Jackson.

scopecontent.p: The collection contains records related to the Alpha Boule chapter of the Sigma Pi Phi fraternity. Materials include: minutes (1956-1992, with some gaps); correspondence; annual reports; financial records; photographs; governance documents such as constitution and bylaws; guidelines for rituals and ceremonies; a scrapbook of early correspondence, minutes, and other documents; curriculum vitae of members; and Alpha Boule stationery. There is correspondence and other documents from: Henry M. Minton, Daniel B. Taylor, Jr., Melvin Chisum, and E. Theodore Jones. The collection also includes taped interviews of members of the fraternity conducted by Dr. Melvin J. Chisum from 1986-1988.
